"Homecoming Day in the spring?" my old high school buddy roared with
laughter. "What's the matter, don't you guys know that football is the big
collegiate sport? You should come up to State in the fall when we play Tech.
Now that's a Homecoming Day. I'll put you up in the frat house and we'll. .
do a little hubba-hubba and boola-boola...."
People outside of the Hopkins community have difficulty understanding
the lacrosse phenomenon here at Homewood. Unless you hail from Long
Island or Baltimore you are probably unfamiliar with the great ol' Indian
game and its mystique. Lacrosse is as much of an institution at Hopkins as
the hospital or the med school. The tradition is practically as old as the
University itself, going back into the mid-1880s when Hopkins was one of
the first schools to start playing lacrosse. The sport took hold in Bawlamer
and that nurtured the sport at Hopkins and kept it growing. The tradition
was enhanced when the University's team representedthe United States in
the only two Olympic games in which lacrosse was included -- 1928 and
1932.
Lacrosse is the coming out season at Hopkins. People you've never seen
before and never will see again will be in attendance opening day against
Yale arrl 'every home every home game thereafter. Lacrosse has even been
known to draw out the nerdiest of nerds from the bowels of D level (albeit
for only the first half!) Lacrosse brings Hopkins recognition the likes of
which few other University activities can equal. The cover of Sports
Illustrated was once adorned with the "spring thing" at Homewood.
Lacrosse is the Great
Equalizer. While other sports may suffer their ups and downs, the lean years
are few and far between for "the fastest game on foot". While other Blue Jay
squads struggle on a level with the Haverfords and Swarthmores,
Montclair States, Galludets etc. lacrosse allows Hopkins rooters the luxury of
competing with the Marylands, Navys and Virginias on equal footing while
standing far above the normal shrines of collegiate sports, be it Ohio State,
UCLA, Penn State et al.
Lacrosse is the elixir of youth which draws former Blue Jays back to the
nest to be revitalized and lets them relive the old glorious days of ought-two
"when we did things we ought not too, hch, heh, Harry!" It brings
obscenities and threats of violence to the lips of even the meekest-looking
septogenarian. "One hundred, and eight, one hundred and nine, one hundred
and ten, WE WANT MORE!"
Lacrosse brings Hopkins fans down to the blue-collar, beer guzzling,
referee-baiting level of all other sports fans. Philosophy and physics majors
side by side descend from the ivory tower to share an illogical but yet
irrefutable hatred of the University of Maryland; a hatred which elevates
Terrapin standouts to levels of infamy usually reserved for the archvillains of
mankind.
Lacrosse brings more people to a small urban university for a game with
Virginia than to the second game of the major league baseball season being
played just blocks away.
Lacrosse even causes major college newspapers tb run sports phao essays
on page one.
Lacrosse: WE WANT MORE!
----Steve Levin

"Hey Harry, what's that?"
"I don't know,Sam, but I think it's a girl!"
"A girl? What's she doing here? Isn't Hopkins an
all-boy's school?"
Not anymore, a passing wag might have commented
back in the fall of 1970 when, as part of a new co-ed
Policy, 94 female transfer students were admitted to
Hopkins. Previously the only women admitted were grad
students or some undergrads as "special students."
The reaction to these first female pioneers at Hopkins
was strangely mixed. There seemed to be a mystique as to
what an actual woman student was. Some professors
actually believed the presence of women was to act as a
kind of "civilizing influence" in the classroom
In an effort to clarify misconceptions and raise public
consciousness of women's role in the academic
community, the M. Carey Thomas Women's Center was
created. The center's members worked toward the
acceptance of women on campus and helped women in
their efforts to adjust to their new surroundings.
These first efforts focused on basic issues such as the
establishment of health facilities for women, and in '73
sponsored a festival, "Next Step," which showed the
positive outgrowths of women's ambitions.
Since that time, the Women's Center has lost
momentum because many of its members have graduated
and women, at large, have become a more integrated part
of the Hopkins community. Today, there are 607
undergraduate female students at Hopkins. Their interests
range from the Humanities to the Natural Sciences
(Natural Sciences being, of course, the largest area of
enrollment) with full participation in the college
curriculum.
The question still remains, however, as to what women
are all about, what their role is in an academic setting, and
what it conceivably should be. In response to these
questions, a women's committee was informally
established a year and a half ago to discuss the idea of
women's programs at Hopkins. The group is composed of

male and female faculty members, graduate and
undergraduate students, who are concerned about
women's existence at Hopkins.
As a result of their concern, several courses have been
offered that are specifically geared to women as subject
matter and to women's influence through the feminist
movement. Until this point, women's courses had been
offered on an irregular basis. In the spring of'71, the first
women's course was offered, but not given for credit.
Subsequent courses have been offered for credit but not
through any kind of organized movement.
The philosophy behind the present group bases on the
development of an ongoing core of courses to be offered
on a regular basis. According to Donna Haroway, a
professor in the History of Science Department, these
courses will take "an eclectic point of view and touch on
many different concerns." Examples of this are issues
touching on political theory, art, politics, and basic
primate behavior.
The four courses offered this year by the women's
studies group have had overwhelming student response
with an exceptionally large student turn-out. The specific

courses offered are: Sexuality and Politics, Women and
Art, Women and Politics, and Sex, Dominance, and
Aggression. These courses all differ in their approaches.
For instance, Sexuality and Politics, taught by Dr. John
Pocock from the History Department, and Nancy
Hartsock, a Political Science professor and editor of the
feminist quarterly, Quest concentrates on myths and
symbols while Donna Harroway's course focuses on
"research used in social and political situations."
Next year, courses offered will include one by Dr. Ron
Walters of the History Department, called "Social and
Cultural History of the U.S." which will include a section
on the anglo-american family. Other tentative courses will
come from the Near Eastern, Classics, and Anthropology
departments.
According to the women's studies group, the failure to
create a women's studies department has been because of
an effort to bring women's studies into the mainstream of
academic disciplines and not regard women as separate
entities. To this extent, women are seen to be important
in many areas of academic study. Their inclusion within
these areas is equally important.,

"After 37 years of loyal and faithful service, I have a
plaque, $1,360, and brown lung." --Thomas Malone, a
retired Stevens worker
J.P. Stevens and Co. began as a small family-owned
textile manufacturer in Massachusetts in 1813. Since
World War II, it has merged with 10 companies, becoming
the second largest corporate giant in the textile industry,
and the nation's no. 1 labor law violator.
In their drive to avoid unionization, J.P. Stevens has
established a policy of closing Northeastern plants and
moving south. The reasons for this are clear: traditionally
the south has been the country's most hostile region
towards industrial unionization. So-called "Right to
Work" laws, racial antagonism, and depressed local
economies
have combined to stifle attempts to
unionize Southern workers. Taking advantage of this
situation, Stevens has closed all but five small northern
plants and now operates 80 plants in southern states.
Stevens relocated its textile mills in Dixie for one
essential reason: to make more profit at the expense of
their workers. The record indicates they have succeeded.
In wages alone, the Stevens worker receives 31% less than
the average American factory worker. This disparity is
magnified by fringe benefits and working conditions so
primitive that even Andrew Carnegie would smile.
The J.P. Stevens pension system makes it possible to
work for the company for 47 years and receive the
generous sum of $60 a month upon retirement. In health
care, J.P. Stevens has pioneered such practices as ordering

an electrocuted worker out of a hospital intensive care
unit and back to work in order to avoid increasing their
worker-compensation liability.
If any group of workers has ever needed an adequate
health-care plan, it is those at J.P. Stevens. The
Company's mills have frequently been cited for
dangerously exposed saw blades, steam pipes, fan belts,
etc. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration
(OSHA) has found cotton dust levels in some Stevens
plants to be three times the maximum allowed tinder
tedefal standards. The result is, as many as one in three of
the exposed workers are likely to develop a disabling
respiratory disease called "brown lung." According to an
OSHA investigation, the seven Stevens plants in Roanoke
Rapids, N.C. have noise levels over 20 times in excess of
those prescribed by law. Consequently, scientists predict
that almost half of the workers in these plants will suffer
severe hearing loss by the time they retire.
Problems with wages, benefits and working conditions
are especially acute for the 20% of the Stevens work force
that is black. Twice Federal Courts have ruled the
company in violation of laws against employment
discrimination. In December 1975, a U.S. District Court
ruled that the company management in Roanoke Rapids
had, since 1969, engaged in a series of discriminatory
practices including: 1) hiring on the basis of race; 2)
reserving clerical and supervisory jobs for white
employees; 3) discrimination against blacks in layoffs and
recalls; 4) paying blacks substantially lower wages than
whites.
A single worker cannot hope to effectively alter the
policies of a large corporation like J.P. Stevens. They
simply lack the necessary economic and political leverage.
The alternative, of course, is for the workers to unionize
so that they may deal with management on a more
equitable basis. An increasing number of Stevens
employees have recognized this and have opted for union
representation.
Federal law guarantees industrial workers the right to
freely vote on union membership. If a majority of the
workers at a plant favor union representation, the
company is required to negotiate "in good faith" with the
union. The agency with jurisdiction to enforce the
Federal labor laws is the National Labor Relations Board
(NLRB). Since 1963, the NLRB has brought 16 cases
against J.P. Stevens in the Federal Courts and the
company has been found guilty 14 times. Through these
suits, 125 workers dismissed for union activities have been

reinstated, regaining $1.3 million in back pay.
Firing is not the only weapon in Stevens' anti-union
arsenal. The NLRB and the courts have found the
company guilty, time after time of 1) coercive
interrogation of workers; 2) surveillance of suspected
union activists, both on and off company property; 3)
denying overtime to union supporters; 4)discriminatorily.
applying plant rules.
One of the company's favorite tactics is to threaten
closure of a plant if the workers attempt to unionize.
Most of the Stevens plants are located in small towns
where jobs are scarce, and such threats are a powerful
means of intimidation. In fact, Stevens completely closed
down its Statesboror, Ga. plant in 1975, rather than obey
a U.S. Court of Appeals order to negotiate with the
union.
The most prominent current example of J.P. Stevens'
contempt for the law is at the plants in Roanoke Rapids.
There, in 1974, the union won an election among the
workers, but since that time, the NLRB regional director
has found that the company "negotiated with the Union
in bad faith and with no intent of entering into any final
or binding collective bargaining agreement." Once again,
the company is being taken to court for violating the
nation's labor laws.
After 15 years of litigation, is has become clear that the
courts alone cannot effectively force J.P. Stevens to
respect the rights of its workers. At this point, the most
effective method of bringing J.P. Stevens to its senses is a
swift kick in its pocketbook. This past January, a
aationwide boycott of J.P. Stevens products was begun.
The AFL-CIO has committed $15 million over the next
10 years in support of the boycott. In addition to labor
unions, numerous religious, political and civil rights
groups are promoting the boycott.
The boycott will not be easy. Stevens products'are sold
under a score of different brand names such as: Utica
sheets, towels and blankets, Tastemaker sheets, towels and
carpets, Peanuts (the cartoon) sheets, Gulistan carpets,
and Yves St. Laurent sheets. And the boycott will not
require a great sacrifice on the part of consumers. There
are plenty of other brands of sheets, towels and carpets.
Just make the small effort necessary to learn the Stevens
brands, don't buy them, and urge your family and friends
to do the same.
The implications of this boycott are extraordinary. Not
only can the boycott bring justice to thousands of Stevens
workers, but if it is effective, it can be the key to the
unionization of hundreds of thousa.nds of industrial
workers throughout the South.

Displaying uncharacteristic offensive strength in the
first half, the Hopkins lacrosse
team rolled over
the Virginia Cavaliers, 15-9, before a chilled
standing-room only crowd Saturday afternoon at
Homewood Field.
The impressive victory, coupled with Maryland's The
impressive victory, coupled with Maryland's near-overtime
loss to UMBC (the Terps won 13-12) enabled the Jays to
jump into. the number two spot in the nation, trailing
only Cornell. Hopkins plays Cornell this weekend.
The Blue Jays (now 5-0) erupted for seven first period
goals en route to a 10-2 halftime lead, and then coasted
through the second half as the fourth-ranked visitors
troed to recpver.
Hopkins's first-half explosion was surprising in light of
the style of play exhibited so far this season by the
Homewood ten. In previous contests, JHU has been
sluggish through the first half, before coming on strongly
in the third and fourth quarters of play.
"We were just ready to play today," said Hopkins head
coach Henry Ciccarone.
Was the Coach surprised at the relative ease with which
tL• Jays handled the previously undefeated Wahoos?
"Yes, I was," Ciccarone replied. "I expected a real
dogfight."
The Jays came out roaring from the opening face-off
and never looked back. Freshman Frank Cutrone got the
game's first goal less than one minute into the contest
when he took a Rich Hirsch pass and gunned the ball past
the Cavalier goalie.
Although the score remained 1-0 over the next five
minutes, Hopkins began to assert itself. Play was
continually in the Virginia defensive zone.
At the 5:38 mark, the roof began to fall in for the
visitors to Homewood. Within two and one-half minutes,
the Hays had pumped five goals past the beleaguered
Wahoo net minder and suddenly held a 6-0 lead.

Jay midfielder Dave Huntley opened the barrage when
he connected on a fifteen-foot shot while JHU held an
extra-man advantage. Bob DeSimone, Huntley, Tom
Myrick and Hirsch followed in quick succession to give
Hopkins its awesome lead. Cutrone tallied his second
score of the period several minutes late and JHU held a
7-0 advantage after fifteen minutes of play.
Freshman Wayne Davis opened the second period
scoring with a twelve-footer. Virginia, after having been
shut out for twenty minutes, finally broke into the
scoring column,"cutting" the lead to 8-1.
The teams traded goals through the rest of the quarter
with Mike O'Neill and Myrick adding Blue Jay scores to
bring on the 10-2 halftime margin.
Virginia fought valiantly throughout the second half to
try and get back into the game, but unsuccessfully.
Although they outplayed the Jays for most of the half,
the visitors were unable to close the gap.

Wahoos outscored the Jays 6-3 in the third quarter and
trailed 13-8 as the final fifteen minutes began. Virginia
then added a goal midway through the fourth quarter to
close to within four goals, and it appeared as though the
Cavaliers were gaining the momentum.
However, faster than you can say Eamon McEneaney,
Huntley and Cutrone fired home goals and the Hopkins
unblemished record was to remain intact.
"We decided to reverse our pattern this week,"
Ciccarone said following the game. "Maybe when we got
ahead, it's human nature to let down. Anyway, there's no
question that the first half was the best thirty minutes of
lacrosse we've played this season."
The Jays will have to play equally well for the entire
sixty minutes if they hope to keep their undefeated
season intact next Saturday when they travel to Ithaca.
New York to face the Big Red of Cornell.

People outside of the Hopkins community have difficulty understanding
the lacrosse phenomenon here at Homewood. Unless you hail from Long
Island or Baltimore you are probably unfamiliar with the great ol' Indian
game and its mystique. Lacrosse is as much of an institution at Hopkins as
the hospital or the med school. The tradition is practically as old as the
University itself, going back into the mid-1880s when Hopkins was one of
the first schools to start playing lacrosse. The sport took hold in Bawlamer
and that nurtured the sport at Hopkins and kept it growing. The tradition
was enhanced when the University's team representedthe United States in
the only two Olympic games in which lacrosse was included -- 1928 and
1932.
Lacrosse is the coming out season at Hopkins. People you've never seen
before and never will see again will be in attendance opening day against
Yale arrl 'every home every home game thereafter. Lacrosse has even been
known to draw out the nerdiest of nerds from the bowels of D level (albeit
for only the first half!) Lacrosse brings Hopkins recognition the likes of
which few other University activities can equal. The cover of Sports
Illustrated was once adorned with the "spring thing" at Homewood.

Equalizer. While other sports may suffer their ups and downs, the lean years
are few and far between for "the fastest game on foot". While other Blue Jay
squads struggle on a level with the Haverfords and Swarthmores,
Montclair States, Galludets etc. lacrosse allows Hopkins rooters the luxury of
competing with the Marylands, Navys and Virginias on equal footing while
standing far above the normal shrines of collegiate sports, be it Ohio State,
UCLA, Penn State et al.
Lacrosse is the elixir of youth which draws former Blue Jays back to the
nest to be revitalized and lets them relive the old glorious days of ought-two
"when we did things we ought not too, hch, heh, Harry!" It brings
obscenities and threats of violence to the lips of even the meekest-looking
septogenarian. "One hundred, and eight, one hundred and nine, one hundred
and ten, WE WANT MORE!"
Lacrosse brings Hopkins fans down to the blue-collar, beer guzzling,
referee-baiting level of all other sports fans. Philosophy and physics majors
side by side descend from the ivory tower to share an illogical but yet
irrefutable hatred of the University of Maryland; a hatred which elevates
Terrapin standouts to levels of infamy usually reserved for the archvillains of
mankind.
Lacrosse brings more people to a small urban university for a game with
Virginia than to the second game of the major league baseball season being

"Hey Harry, what's that?"
"I don't know,Sam, but I think it's a girl!"
"A girl? What's she doing here? Isn't Hopkins an
all-boy's school?"
Not anymore, a passing wag might have commented
back in the fall of 1970 when, as part of a new co-ed
Policy, 94 female transfer students were admitted to
Hopkins. Previously the only women admitted were grad
students or some undergrads as "special students."
The reaction to these first female pioneers at Hopkins
was strangely mixed. There seemed to be a mystique as to
what an actual woman student was. Some professors
actually believed the presence of women was to act as a
kind of "civilizing influence" in the classroom
In an effort to clarify misconceptions and raise public
consciousness of women's role in the academic
community, the M. Carey Thomas Women's Center was
created. The center's members worked toward the
acceptance of women on campus and helped women in
their efforts to adjust to their new surroundings.
These first efforts focused on basic issues such as the
establishment of health facilities for women, and in '73
sponsored a festival, "Next Step," which showed the
positive outgrowths of women's ambitions.
Since that time, the Women's Center has lost
momentum because many of its members have graduated
and women, at large, have become a more integrated part
of the Hopkins community. Today, there are 607
undergraduate female students at Hopkins. Their interests
range from the Humanities to the Natural Sciences
(Natural Sciences being, of course, the largest area of
enrollment) with full participation in the college
curriculum.
The question still remains, however, as to what women
are all about, what their role is in an academic setting, and
what it conceivably should be. In response to these
questions, a women's committee was informally
established a year and a half ago to discuss the idea of
women's programs at Hopkins. The group is composed of

male and female faculty members, graduate and
undergraduate students, who are concerned about
women's existence at Hopkins.
As a result of their concern, several courses have been
offered that are specifically geared to women as subject
matter and to women's influence through the feminist
movement. Until this point, women's courses had been
offered on an irregular basis. In the spring of'71, the first
women's course was offered, but not given for credit.
Subsequent courses have been offered for credit but not
through any kind of organized movement.
The philosophy behind the present group bases on the
development of an ongoing core of courses to be offered
on a regular basis. According to Donna Haroway, a
professor in the History of Science Department, these
courses will take "an eclectic point of view and touch on
many different concerns." Examples of this are issues
touching on political theory, art, politics, and basic
primate behavior.
The four courses offered this year by the women's
studies group have had overwhelming student response
with an exceptionally large student turn-out. The specific

courses offered are: Sexuality and Politics, Women and
Art, Women and Politics, and Sex, Dominance, and
Aggression. These courses all differ in their approaches.
For instance, Sexuality and Politics, taught by Dr. John
Pocock from the History Department, and Nancy
Hartsock, a Political Science professor and editor of the
feminist quarterly, Quest concentrates on myths and
symbols while Donna Harroway's course focuses on
"research used in social and political situations."
Next year, courses offered will include one by Dr. Ron
Walters of the History Department, called "Social and
Cultural History of the U.S." which will include a section
on the anglo-american family. Other tentative courses will
come from the Near Eastern, Classics, and Anthropology
departments.
According to the women's studies group, the failure to
create a women's studies department has been because of
an effort to bring women's studies into the mainstream of
academic disciplines and not regard women as separate
entities. To this extent, women are seen to be important
in many areas of academic study. Their inclusion within
these areas is equally important.,

"After 37 years of loyal and faithful service, I have a
plaque, $1,360, and brown lung." --Thomas Malone, a
retired Stevens worker
J.P. Stevens and Co. began as a small family-owned
textile manufacturer in Massachusetts in 1813. Since
World War II, it has merged with 10 companies, becoming
the second largest corporate giant in the textile industry,
and the nation's no. 1 labor law violator.
In their drive to avoid unionization, J.P. Stevens has
established a policy of closing Northeastern plants and
moving south. The reasons for this are clear: traditionally
the south has been the country's most hostile region
towards industrial unionization. So-called "Right to
Work" laws, racial antagonism, and depressed local
economies
have combined to stifle attempts to
unionize Southern workers. Taking advantage of this
situation, Stevens has closed all but five small northern
plants and now operates 80 plants in southern states.
Stevens relocated its textile mills in Dixie for one
essential reason: to make more profit at the expense of
their workers. The record indicates they have succeeded.
In wages alone, the Stevens worker receives 31% less than
the average American factory worker. This disparity is
magnified by fringe benefits and working conditions so
primitive that even Andrew Carnegie would smile.
The J.P. Stevens pension system makes it possible to
work for the company for 47 years and receive the
generous sum of $60 a month upon retirement. In health
care, J.P. Stevens has pioneered such practices as ordering

an electrocuted worker out of a hospital intensive care
unit and back to work in order to avoid increasing their
worker-compensation liability.
If any group of workers has ever needed an adequate
health-care plan, it is those at J.P. Stevens. The
Company's mills have frequently been cited for
dangerously exposed saw blades, steam pipes, fan belts,
etc. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration
(OSHA) has found cotton dust levels in some Stevens
plants to be three times the maximum allowed tinder
tedefal standards. The result is, as many as one in three of
the exposed workers are likely to develop a disabling
respiratory disease called "brown lung." According to an
OSHA investigation, the seven Stevens plants in Roanoke
Rapids, N.C. have noise levels over 20 times in excess of
those prescribed by law. Consequently, scientists predict
that almost half of the workers in these plants will suffer
severe hearing loss by the time they retire.
Problems with wages, benefits and working conditions
are especially acute for the 20% of the Stevens work force
that is black. Twice Federal Courts have ruled the
company in violation of laws against employment
discrimination. In December 1975, a U.S. District Court
ruled that the company management in Roanoke Rapids
had, since 1969, engaged in a series of discriminatory
practices including: 1) hiring on the basis of race; 2)
reserving clerical and supervisory jobs for white
employees; 3) discrimination against blacks in layoffs and
recalls; 4) paying blacks substantially lower wages than
whites.
A single worker cannot hope to effectively alter the
policies of a large corporation like J.P. Stevens. They
simply lack the necessary economic and political leverage.
The alternative, of course, is for the workers to unionize
so that they may deal with management on a more
equitable basis. An increasing number of Stevens
employees have recognized this and have opted for union
representation.
Federal law guarantees industrial workers the right to
freely vote on union membership. If a majority of the
workers at a plant favor union representation, the
company is required to negotiate "in good faith" with the
union. The agency with jurisdiction to enforce the
Federal labor laws is the National Labor Relations Board
(NLRB). Since 1963, the NLRB has brought 16 cases
against J.P. Stevens in the Federal Courts and the
company has been found guilty 14 times. Through these
suits, 125 workers dismissed for union activities have been

reinstated, regaining $1.3 million in back pay.
Firing is not the only weapon in Stevens' anti-union
arsenal. The NLRB and the courts have found the
company guilty, time after time of 1) coercive
interrogation of workers; 2) surveillance of suspected
union activists, both on and off company property; 3)
denying overtime to union supporters; 4)discriminatorily.
applying plant rules.
One of the company's favorite tactics is to threaten
closure of a plant if the workers attempt to unionize.
Most of the Stevens plants are located in small towns
where jobs are scarce, and such threats are a powerful
means of intimidation. In fact, Stevens completely closed
down its Statesboror, Ga. plant in 1975, rather than obey
a U.S. Court of Appeals order to negotiate with the
union.
The most prominent current example of J.P. Stevens'
contempt for the law is at the plants in Roanoke Rapids.
There, in 1974, the union won an election among the
workers, but since that time, the NLRB regional director
has found that the company "negotiated with the Union
in bad faith and with no intent of entering into any final
or binding collective bargaining agreement." Once again,
the company is being taken to court for violating the
nation's labor laws.
After 15 years of litigation, is has become clear that the
courts alone cannot effectively force J.P. Stevens to
respect the rights of its workers. At this point, the most
effective method of bringing J.P. Stevens to its senses is a
swift kick in its pocketbook. This past January, a
aationwide boycott of J.P. Stevens products was begun.
The AFL-CIO has committed $15 million over the next
10 years in support of the boycott. In addition to labor
unions, numerous religious, political and civil rights
groups are promoting the boycott.
The boycott will not be easy. Stevens products'are sold
under a score of different brand names such as: Utica
sheets, towels and blankets, Tastemaker sheets, towels and
carpets, Peanuts (the cartoon) sheets, Gulistan carpets,
and Yves St. Laurent sheets. And the boycott will not
require a great sacrifice on the part of consumers. There
are plenty of other brands of sheets, towels and carpets.
Just make the small effort necessary to learn the Stevens
brands, don't buy them, and urge your family and friends
to do the same.
The implications of this boycott are extraordinary. Not
only can the boycott bring justice to thousands of Stevens
workers, but if it is effective, it can be the key to the
unionization of hundreds of thousa.nds of industrial
workers throughout the South.
Submitted by The Young Democrats

Displaying uncharacteristic offensive strength in the
first half, the Hopkins lacrosse
team rolled over
the Virginia Cavaliers, 15-9, before a chilled
standing-room only crowd Saturday afternoon at
Homewood Field.
The impressive victory, coupled with Maryland's The
impressive victory, coupled with Maryland's near-overtime
loss to UMBC (the Terps won 13-12) enabled the Jays to
jump into. the number two spot in the nation, trailing
only Cornell. Hopkins plays Cornell this weekend.
The Blue Jays (now 5-0) erupted for seven first period
goals en route to a 10-2 halftime lead, and then coasted
through the second half as the fourth-ranked visitors
troed to recpver.
Hopkins's first-half explosion was surprising in light of
the style of play exhibited so far this season by the
Homewood ten. In previous contests, JHU has been
sluggish through the first half, before coming on strongly
in the third and fourth quarters of play.
"We were just ready to play today," said Hopkins head
coach Henry Ciccarone.
Was the Coach surprised at the relative ease with which
tL• Jays handled the previously undefeated Wahoos?
"Yes, I was," Ciccarone replied. "I expected a real
dogfight."
The Jays came out roaring from the opening face-off
and never looked back. Freshman Frank Cutrone got the
game's first goal less than one minute into the contest
when he took a Rich Hirsch pass and gunned the ball past
the Cavalier goalie.
Although the score remained 1-0 over the next five
minutes, Hopkins began to assert itself. Play was
continually in the Virginia defensive zone.
At the 5:38 mark, the roof began to fall in for the
visitors to Homewood. Within two and one-half minutes,
the Hays had pumped five goals past the beleaguered
Wahoo net minder and suddenly held a 6-0 lead.

Jay midfielder Dave Huntley opened the barrage when
he connected on a fifteen-foot shot while JHU held an
extra-man advantage. Bob DeSimone, Huntley, Tom
Myrick and Hirsch followed in quick succession to give
Hopkins its awesome lead. Cutrone tallied his second
score of the period several minutes late and JHU held a
7-0 advantage after fifteen minutes of play.
Freshman Wayne Davis opened the second period
scoring with a twelve-footer. Virginia, after having been
shut out for twenty minutes, finally broke into the
scoring column,"cutting" the lead to 8-1.
The teams traded goals through the rest of the quarter
with Mike O'Neill and Myrick adding Blue Jay scores to
bring on the 10-2 halftime margin.
Virginia fought valiantly throughout the second half to
try and get back into the game, but unsuccessfully.
Although they outplayed the Jays for most of the half,
the visitors were unable to close the gap.

Capitalizing on an effective man-advantage offense, the
Wahoos outscored the Jays 6-3 in the third quarter and
trailed 13-8 as the final fifteen minutes began. Virginia
then added a goal midway through the fourth quarter to
close to within four goals, and it appeared as though the
Cavaliers were gaining the momentum.
However, faster than you can say Eamon McEneaney,
Huntley and Cutrone fired home goals and the Hopkins
unblemished record was to remain intact.
"We decided to reverse our pattern this week,"
Ciccarone said following the game. "Maybe when we got
ahead, it's human nature to let down. Anyway, there's no
question that the first half was the best thirty minutes of
lacrosse we've played this season."
The Jays will have to play equally well for the entire
sixty minutes if they hope to keep their undefeated
season intact next Saturday when they travel to Ithaca.
New York to face the Big Red of Cornell.

Pegged Coach Denny Cox's new juggernaut by a local
sportcaster, the Hopkins baseball team started out this
season to prove that statement and now find themselves
undefeated in league play and 5-3 overall.
Opening the season the Thursday before spring break,
Hopkins' baseball Blue Jays swept Division II Mt. St.
Mary's, 3-2 and 5-4. Despite a wind chill factor below
freezing, a combination of defense, timely hitting from
Dennis Holt, and excellent pitching from Steffan "Three
Finger" Burns and Mike Santo made the games real crowd
pleasers for the six or so in attendance.
A doubleheader March 26 found Hopkins demolishing
MAC rival Haverford, 5-0 and 15-6. The first game,
pitched and won by freshman Parreira, was over when the
third batter, Dave Emala, stepped to the plate in the first
inning and cracked a home run to center.
The second game saw Bob Babb and Dave Lewing
power the Jays' 15 run attack as Jason Sussman pitched a
complete game victory under no pressure.
Besides the obvious hitting prowess displayed over the
weak Haverford team, the Jays also ran rampant over the
basepaths led by senior Bob Babb's 5 stolen bases. Coach
Cox credited first baseman Babb for the team's
baserunning success in a recent Evening Sun article.
"All our players are much more confident and
aggressive on the bases because of him," the coach
explained. While recovering from a serious knee injury,
Babb stole 18 bases in 18 attempts last year while
providing .390 hitting from his leadoff batting slot.
On the Tuesday of spring vacation, Hopkins and a
prestigious University of Baltimore team took to the Jays'
field behind the Snack Bar, this time with a better crowd
on hand. According to a News American article,
."reputation was about the only thing BU had over
Hopkins. The Jays had better hitting, running, and
pitching."
The game was a slugfest until determined reliever Mike
Santo came into the game with two outs in the top of the
fifth and the Blue Jays ahead 7-6. Over the next four and
one-third innings. Santo didn't allow a single hit or run as
Hopkins tallied twice for a 9-6 final score. Hopkins
collected a dozen hits led by Chuck Ingber and Babb, who
hit two run producing shots.

Up until this game the Jays have had phenomenal .500
hitting from Dave Emala, who provides leadership
through performance with fellow co-captain Bob Babb,
and timely hitting and dependable defense from Dave
Lewing and his crew in the outfield, including Mike April,
Ingber, and Greg Jenkins.
The successful pitching staff has been able to get the
ball over the plate consistently and cleverly, while their
defense was matched by dependable performances from
the regulars.

leddown This broke down, however, as the Jays had a
letdown playing Western Maryland March 7th on a
sometimes snowbound field. Mike Santo, who had earned
his first starting assignment, lost his control and gave up
the middle two runs on wild throwing. Although the score
was tied 2-2 as late as the fifth inning, the Jays lost a 6-3

decision to the weather, but most of all; to themselves.

tomorrow are imperative.
